qas.question: While Knickebein was used my most German crews who used the X-Gerat system?
What frequency did the X-Gerat system use?
What rate per minute did ground transmitters send?
When the bomber crossed the first beam the bomber-aimer did what?
What mechanism cause the bombs to be released?

context: While Knickebein was used by German crews en masse, X-Gerät use was limited to <a0_0>specially trained pathfinder crews<a0_0/>. Special receivers were mounted in He 111s, with a radio mast on the bomber's fuselage. The system worked on a higher frequency (<a1_0>66–77 MHz<a1_0/>, compared to Knickebein's 30–33 MHz). Transmitters on the ground sent pulses at a rate of <a2_0>180<a2_0/> per minute. X-Gerät received and analysed the pulses, giving the pilot both visual and aural "on course" signals. Three beams intersected the beam along the He 111's flight path. The first cross-beam acted as a warning for the bomb-aimer to <a3_0>start the bombing-clock<a3_0/> which he would activate only when the second cross-beam was reached. When the third cross-beam was reached the bomb aimer activated a third trigger, which stopped the first hand of the equipment's clock, with the second hand continuing. When the second hand re-aligned with the first, the bombs were released. The <a4_0>clock's timing<a4_0/> mechanism was co-ordinated with the distances of the intersecting beams from the target so the target was directly below when the bomb release occurred.
